stem: When asked to make a fist, a patient’s index and middle fingers remain extended at the MP, PIP, and DIP joints while digits 4–5 flex. Which lesion best explains this 'Hand of Benediction' sign?

choices.A: Proximal median nerve lesion in the arm/cubital fossa
choices.C: Distal radial nerve compression at the wrist

rationale_correct: Proximal median lesion denervates FDS, FPL, and lateral FDP plus lumbricals to digits 2–3, preventing flexion of digits 1–3 when making a fist.

rationale_distractors.B: Ulnar canal lesions affect digits 4–5 and may cause mild clawing, not the Benediction pattern on making a fist.
rationale_distractors.C: Distal radial compression produces wrist drop and dorsum hand sensory loss; the fist test pattern is median.
rationale_distractors.D: PIN palsy impairs extension, not the flexion pattern described.
rationale_distractors.E: Axillary nerve deficits affect shoulder abduction (deltoid).

evidence.citation: Selski D. Nerve Injuries of the Upper Limb Lecture Notes. Sep 22, 2025.
